title: How to Make a Tulle Skirt

steps.headline: Choose your tulle and elastic.
steps.description: Making a no-sew tulle skirt is easy and all it requires is a lot of tulle and enough elastic to fit around your waist. You will need about 20 yards of tulle to make your skirt. Choose any color of tulle and elastic that you want to use. Elastic is usually only available in black and white, but tulle comes in many different colors. You will also need a sharp pair of scissors to cut the tulle.

steps.headline: Cut the tulle into long, wide strips.
steps.description: Fold your tulle in half width-wise and then use a ruler to measure out sections of tulle that are about 18” (46 cm) wide. Cut out your tulle strips while the fabric is still folded in half and stack them up with the fold intact.

steps.headline: Tie the ends of the elastic together around your model's waist.
steps.description: Just make sure that you can undo the knot if you need to. This will allow you to adjust the width of the waistband later on if needed. If you are sure about the waist measurement, then you can also cut the elastic band to that width and then staple or sew the ends together.

steps.headline: Tie the tulle strips to the elastic band.
steps.description: Next, you will need to tie your folded tulle strips onto the elastic band. Bring the folded end of the tulle strip behind the elastic and pull it up above the level of the elastic slightly. Then, bring the ends of the tulle strip up in front of the elastic strip and thread them through the loop of the folded tulle. Pull the strips all the way through the loop to create a knot. This will secure the tulle strip around the elastic. Repeat this process all the way around the elastic until you have completely covered the elastic with the tulle strips. Make sure to push the knots together as you go to ensure that the skirt will be as full as possible.

steps.headline: Spread and scrunch the tulle as desired.
steps.description: Once you have all of the strips on the elastic, use your hands to spread out and scrunch the tulle. Spreading it out will give a full, flowy effect, and it will also help to ensure that the strips overlap each other. Scrunching the tulle will also add fullness and it will make the skirt appear more structured.

steps.headline: Trim the bottom of the skirt if needed.
steps.description: If the skirt is longer than you wanted it to be, then you can trim the bottom to shorten it. Have your model try on the skirt, or put the skirt on a dress form, and then trim around the bottom edges to get the skirt to the desired length. Make sure to cut carefully and get the edges as even as possible.

steps.headline: Purchase tulle, lining, and a wide band of elastic.
steps.description: You can use any color of tulle that you want. Just keep in mind that you will need a lot of it to make your skirt, so try to choose tulle that is on sale or reasonably priced to help keep your costs down. You will also need fabric to line your skirt. You can use any lightweight fabric, such as a cotton or broadcloth. Also, make sure to purchase a wide band of elastic. You will need enough elastic to go around your waist. You will need a piece of lining fabric that is 2.5 times the width of your waist measurement. For example, if your waist measures 30” (76 cm), then you will need 75” (191 cm) of lining fabric. The length of the fabric should be the desired length of your tulle skirt plus 1” (2.5 cm). You will need a large amount of tulle to create a gathered skirt. Plan to purchase 20 yards for an adult size skirt or about 10 yards for a child size skirt. Elastic usually comes in black and white. Choose the option that works best with the tulle you are using. Make sure to measure your waist before you buy your elastic and get enough elastic to fit around your waist.

steps.headline: Hem the long edges of your lining.
steps.description: While you do not need to hem your tulle, it is a good idea to hem your lining material. This is because your lining may fray if it is left unhemmed. To hem your lining, fold over the top and bottom edges of your lining piece by ¼” (0.6 cm) and sew along the edges to secure them. If desired, you may fold over the fabric again and sew again to completely cover the raw edge, but this is optional.

steps.headline: Sew the short edges of the lining together.
steps.description: Next, you will need to sew together the short edges of the lining fabric to connect the lining fabric in a circle. Match up the edges of the lining fabric so that they are even and then sew a straight stitch about ½” (1.3 cm) from the edge of the fabric.

steps.headline: Measure and cut your elastic.
steps.description: Your elastic piece will need to be the same size as your waist measurement. Measure the elastic and then cut it to the same length as your waist measurement.

steps.headline: Sew the ends of your elastic together.
steps.description: After you have cut your elastic to the desired length, line up the edges so that they are slightly overlapping (by about ¼” or 0.6 cm). Then, sew a straight stitch to secure the ends of the elastic together.

steps.headline: Gather and pin the lining to your elastic.
steps.description: Begin pinning your lining fabric circle to the elastic band. As you pin the lining, gather it so that you will be able to secure the edges of the entire piece around your elastic band. This may require some trial and error. To help you gather the lining fabric evenly, pin the lining to the elastic band on one side and then pin the opposite end of the lining fabric circle to the opposite side of the elastic band. Repeat this for the edges of the lining fabric circle that are now opposite each other so that you have four corners pinned to the elastic band. Then, gather the areas in between the four corners. You may place your elastic piece on a dress form, on your model, or work without either. However, be careful not to stick your model with the pins if you decide to do the pinning with the elastic around their waist.

steps.headline: Sew the lining onto the elastic.
steps.description: After you are satisfied with the gathering of your lining fabric circle, sew the lining onto the elastic. Sew a straight stitch all the way around the pinned edges of your lining and elastic to secure them together. Remove the pins as you go.

steps.headline: Gather and pin the tulle to the elastic.
steps.description: You will need to repeat the same gathering and pinning process with your tulle fabric. However, the tulle will be in a long strip rather than in a circle. You will also want the tulle to be much fuller and more gathered than the lining. Aim for about 4 yards ( 3.6 meters) of tulle for every 12" (30 cm) of elastic. Lay the tulle over the lining fabric and begin pinning it in place.

steps.headline: Sew the tulle onto the elastic.
steps.description: After you have finished gathering and pinning the tulle to the elastic, you will need to sew the tulle in place. Sew a straight stitch all the way around the edges of the tulle and elastic to secure them. Sew about ¼” (0.6 cm) from the edges of the tulle. If desired, you can make a separate pass about ¼” (0.6 cm) from your first one. Remove the pins as you sew.

steps.headline: Cut the bottom edge of the tulle to adjust the length.
steps.description: Once you have finished sewing the tulle onto the elastic, your skirt is ready to wear! However, if you want to adjust the length, then you can cut along the bottom edges of the tulle. Make sure that you do not cut the tulle shorter than your lining. Your tulle should be about 1” (2.5 cm) or longer than your lining or it may be visible when you wear the skirt.

Elastic is usually only available in black and white, but tulle comes in many different colors. You will also need a sharp pair of scissors to cut the tulle. Cut the tulle into long, wide strips. Fold your tulle in half width-wise and then use a ruler to measure out sections of tulle that are about 18” (46 cm) wide. Just make sure that you can undo the knot if you need to. This will allow you to adjust the width of the waistband later on if needed. Next, you will need to tie your folded tulle strips onto the elastic band. Bring the folded end of the tulle strip behind the elastic and pull it up above the level of the elastic slightly. Then, bring the ends of the tulle strip up in front of the elastic strip and thread them through the loop of the folded tulle. Pull the strips all the way through the loop to create a knot. You will need a large amount of tulle to create a gathered skirt. Plan to purchase 20 yards for an adult size skirt or about 10 yards for a child size skirt. Elastic usually comes in black and white. Choose the option that works best with the tulle you are using. Make sure to measure your waist before you buy your elastic and get enough elastic to fit around your waist. Hem the long edges of your lining. While you do not need to hem your tulle, it is a good idea to hem your lining material. This is because your lining may fray if it is left unhemmed. Next, you will need to sew together the short edges of the lining fabric to connect the lining fabric in a circle. Match up the edges of the lining fabric so that they are even and then sew a straight stitch about ½” (1.3 cm) from the edge of the fabric. Measure and cut your elastic. Your elastic piece will need to be the same size as your waist measurement. Measure the elastic and then cut it to the same length as your waist measurement. Sew the ends of your elastic together. After you have cut your elastic to the desired length, line up the edges so that they are slightly overlapping (by about ¼” or 0.6 cm). Then, sew a straight stitch to secure the ends of the elastic together. Gather and pin the lining to your elastic. Begin pinning your lining fabric circle to the elastic band. As you pin the lining, gather it so that you will be able to secure the edges of the entire piece around your elastic band. This may require some trial and error. To help you gather the lining fabric evenly, pin the lining to the elastic band on one side and then pin the opposite end of the lining fabric circle to the opposite side of the elastic band. Repeat this for the edges of the lining fabric circle that are now opposite each other so that you have four corners pinned to the elastic band. Then, gather the areas in between the four corners. However, be careful not to stick your model with the pins if you decide to do the pinning with the elastic around their waist. Sew the lining onto the elastic. After you are satisfied with the gathering of your lining fabric circle, sew the lining onto the elastic. Sew a straight stitch all the way around the pinned edges of your lining and elastic to secure them together. Remove the pins as you go. Gather and pin the tulle to the elastic. You will need to repeat the same gathering and pinning process with your tulle fabric. However, the tulle will be in a long strip rather than in a circle. You will also want the tulle to be much fuller and more gathered than the lining. Aim for about 4 yards ( 3.6 meters) of tulle for every 12" (30 cm) of elastic. Lay the tulle over the lining fabric and begin pinning it in place. Sew the tulle onto the elastic. After you have finished gathering and pinning the tulle to the elastic, you will need to sew the tulle in place. Sew a straight stitch all the way around the edges of the tulle and elastic to secure them. Sew about ¼” (0.6 cm) from the edges of the tulle. If desired, you can make a separate pass about ¼” (0.6 cm) from your first one. Remove the pins as you sew. Cut the bottom edge of the tulle to adjust the length. Once you have finished sewing the tulle onto the elastic, your skirt is ready to wear! However, if you want to adjust the length, then you can cut along the bottom edges of the tulle. Make sure that you do not cut the tulle shorter than your lining. Your tulle should be about 1” (2.5 cm) or longer than your lining or it may be visible when you wear the skirt.
